title: What should someone know before using copyrighted music for home videos? - Quora

response.answer_text: Most recorded music is covered by a copyright. Using someone else’s music in your video is copyright infringement, even if you don’t sell or widely distribute the video. If it’s a registered copyright, you can be fined a substantial sum if the copyright holder found out and chose to sue. Each use is potentially multiple infringements as there are different rights holders for music and lyrics, and adding music to a video requires “synchronization rights”. There is a lot of music out there for which the copyright holder has already granted permission for you to use their music. Creative Commons licensed music is a good example. You can generally obtain permission to use someone else’s copyrighted music for your home video, sometimes for a small fee. There are a large number of royalty-free music sites on the Internet. If you use someone else’s music in your home video and post it to sites like YouTube or Vimeo, even if it’s not public, it’s likely to be detected. Doing so is also a violation of the terms of service and can get the account suspended or removed. YouTube will sometimes simply remove the audio from the video to ameliorate the problem.

That published music is the property of someone (who I assume is not you) so if you use it without permission/payment then it is the equivalent of my using your car to drive myself around. You should technically ask permission before doing anything with published music but unless you use an online service or are Robbie Williams, expect to be ignored - which while not permission, makes it really hard to get permission. If the video is purely private in nature, as in it is only shown to your close family (and by that, I don’t mean the population of New Zealand) then probably everyone will turn a blind eye. As soon as you put it in public like Facegram, YouTube, or play it at your business for visiting customers then you have started to profit from the work of another without paying them, which is of course as mightly uncool as your boss not paying you at the end of the week.

The first thing they should know is that the word is “copyrighted”, not “copywritten”. The second thing they should know is that “copyright” means “the exclusive legal right given to the creator of artistic, literary, and musical works to copy, publish, distribute, or publicly perform those works, or use them in derivative works, and to authorize others to do the same.” The third thing they should know is that publicly showing or distributing a video that uses music without the authorization of the music’s copyright owner is copyright infringement, which is illegal in almost every country in the world. The fourth thing they should know is that being convicted of copyright infringement can result in severe financial penalties (and in rare cases, prison time).

They should know that almost all music may not be freely used, even in home videos, because it violates copyright law. And they should seek permission to use the music, or look for music that is being shared under Creative Commons, is no longer protected by copyright, or is otherwise freely available for such use.
You cannot legal show that video to anyone. Although,vto be frank, this only becomes a problem when you want to put it online. You really can't get “caught” if this never leaves your home.

There are some songs where the original versions are not available, but the instrumentals or covers of the songs are. Some songs also will claim it, but will just put ads on the video and not take it down. There is a tool by YouTube that lets you look up songs and it will tell you which versions of a song are available and in what countries.
